answers.title: Get Response From iOS SDK ViewController
answers.body:
After thinking alot. I have come up with the following idea and when I implemented it, it was working like a charm. Just sharing if anybody also get into this situation.

  1. Create a seperate Protocol Class file(.h file only) in your SDK. Name it whatever you want to name your Delegate. (Also make the class public in your SDK)
  2. Declare required or optional methods in that header file.
  3. Create id delagete instance in each controller. e.g In Controller A, B and C all will have that instance.
  4. When user is trying to integrate the SDK in his application and tries to load Controller A from his client app, then also ask user to set its delegate to self and implement the required methods in his client app view controller.
  5. In SDK when you are moving from Controller A to B and B to C and onwards just keep on passing the self.delegate to next controllers. (This will not create seperate instances, rather it is just pointing one delegate to all other controllers - So No Memory or performance issue occurs as well)
  6. Now when you try to call [self.delegate yourMethodName:@"abc"] from any of the controllers A,B or C etc with different values then it will only be pointing to the mainController where the delegate was set as self.

This is how you can acheive it and you dont need to create different delegates/protocols in different controllers. You can just pass an extra parameter to the delegate method which can denote from which controller this delegate has return.

Thanks

answers.title: Setting up project that uses Cedar for tests, Objective-C Realm and is testing swift Realm models
answers.body:
While waiting for the reply, I managed to find an answer in this fine gentleman's blog post :)

  1. Make sure all your .swift files have Target Membership set only to your main target
  2. As I mentioned in the question, in your Podfile add Realm for main target and Realm/Headers in your test targets
  3. Check that all your test targets have Build Settings -> Product Module Name set to the same value as in your Main target
  4. Final and missing step in my case, add the following path $(CONFIGURATION_TEMP_DIR)/YourMainTargetName.build/DerivedSources in your test targets Build Settings -> Header Search Paths

Do the final step for each test target, if you have multiple, and for each build configuration (ex: Alpha, Beta, Release) if you have multiple.

This also gives us the nice benefit of removing swift classes' membership from our test targets (just like for our Objective-C classes).

Now your tests should run, and Realm shouldn't throw exceptions at you.

title: Setting up project that uses Cedar for tests, Objective-C Realm and is testing swift Realm models
body:
I hope this question is seen and answered by someone from the Realm team

I have a project that uses Cedar to write BDD style tests. I have a mixed project with Objective C and Swift files. Some of these swift files are for custom Realm models. I use CocoaPods to install Realm to my project.

The recommended settings that I've seen so far are the following:

  1. Use Realm/Headers in Podfile for Test targets and just Realm for main target - this solves the +[RLMObjectBase ignoredProperties]: unrecognized selector sent to class error.

answers.title: masksToBounds vs. clipsToBounds
answers.body:
clipsToBounds : with clipsToBounds set to YES, I'll only see the part of the subview that fits within the bounds of the superview. Otherwise, if clipsToBounds is set to NO, I'll see the entire subview, even the parts outside the superview 

masksToBounds: If the masksToBounds property is set to YES, any sublayers of the layer that extend outside its boundaries will be clipped to those boundaries. Think of the layer, in that case, as a window onto its sublayers; anything outside the edges of the window will not be visible. When masksToBounds is NO, no clipping occurs, and any sublayers that extend outside the layer's boundaries will be visible in their entirety (as long as they don't go outside the edges of any superlayer that does have masking enabled).

answers.title: masksToBounds vs. clipsToBounds
answers.body:
masksToBounds

Any sublayers of the layer that extend outside its boundaries will be clipped to those boundaries. Think of the layer, in that case, as a window onto its sublayers; anything outside the edges of the window will not be visible. When masksToBounds is NO, no clipping occurs.

When the value of this property is true, Core Animation creates an implicit clipping mask that matches the bounds of the layer and includes any corner radius effects. If a value for the mask property is also specified, the two masks are multiplied to get the final mask value.

you can get the more information in API Reference.

clipToBounds

The use case for clipsToBounds is more for subviews which are partially outside the main view. For example, I have a (circular) subview on the edge of its parent (rectangular) UIView. If you set clipsToBounds to YES, only half the circle/subview will be shown. If set to NO, the whole circle will show up. Just encountered this so wanted to share

for more information sample link

answers.title: Add "shadow" to view
answers.body:
Ok, so as I understand you want to add shadow to right view and shadow casts over the left view.

To do so:

You can set self.bgDetailsView.clipsToBounds = NO, it will make shadow visible but will also make your shadow to be visible over and below the right view.

You can put right view in container. Set clipsToBounds = NO in right view and make container view a bit bigger to the left.

You can also make a container view with additional CALayer or UIImageView with shadow image. Put your right view to right of this additional view/layer and set in container clipsToBounds = NO.

You can also use shadowPath property of right view layer and put it in container view:

self.bgDetailsView.layer.shadowPath = [UIBezierPath bezierPathWithRect:shadowRect].CGPath;

answers.title: MPNowPlayingInfoCenter remote controls respond incorrectly in iOS 10
answers.body:
The UIEvent delegate way of handling remote control events is no longer recommended for audio/video event handling. Instead, MPRemoteCommandCenter provides a selector-based interface to enable and disable buttons and remote control events, as well as the actions to handle those events.

In the case where content should not be paused or resumed, you will have to explicitly set enabled property for each command to NO AND provide an action, even if it is just a dummy selector that does nothing, in order to disable the buttons in the Control Center properly:

MPRemoteCommandCenter *commandCenter = [MPRemoteCommandCenter sharedCommandCenter];

commandCenter.playCommand.enabled = NO;
[commandCenter.playCommand addTarget:self action:@selector(playAudio)];

commandCenter.pauseCommand.enabled = NO;
[commandCenter.pauseCommand addTarget:self action:@selector(pauseAudio)];

I elaborate on this further with an example from working with AVPlayer here.

title: MPNowPlayingInfoCenter remote controls respond incorrectly in iOS 10
body:
In iOS 10, the control center UI was reworked and since then, play/pause control buttons respond differently.

Content that cannot be paused should not change play/pause buttons in control center on every tap.

Before iOS 10, it was probably checking MPNowPlayingInfoPropertyPlaybackRate and if a content was not paused, it did not change the remote controls. In iOS 10, it changes every single time instantly ignoring MPNowPlayingInfoPropertyPlaybackRate.

answers.title: Why UIView calls getter method of frame on setting its frame?
answers.body:
First thing below code,

Test* inst = [[Test alloc] init];
inst.frame = CGRectMake(0, 0, 123, 123);

should give output like,

Frame!!!
Frame set!!!
Frame!!!
Frame set!!!

I mean two times because first when you alloc and init it and second time when you setting frame.

Now come on main point,

It is not actually calling frame first, it is definitely calling setFrame first but in setFrame method,

   super.frame = frame;

calls frame method so that your output looks like!!

if you will comment super.frame = frame; in setFrame method then your frame method will not get called i think!

You should put breakpoint in both methods and then test!

Update :

Try below code,

 -(void) setFrame:(CGRect) frame {

super.frame = frame;
NSLog(@"Frame set!!!");
}

-(CGRect) frame1 {

NSLog(@"Frame!!!");
return super.frame;
}

or

-(void) setFrame:(CGRect) frame1 {

super.frame = frame1;
NSLog(@"Frame set!!!");
}

-(CGRect) frame1 {

NSLog(@"Frame!!!");
return super.frame;
}

now it will not call frame1 method. You have given method name as frame that means you are overriding super class's frame method so if you call super.frame = frame; then it will definitely call frame method (if overridden then it will get called).

comments.body: Need more context.  If you have an ipa, you can check for the presence of the Swift runtime.  That will tell you the app contains Swift code.  To determine ObjC usage, you'll need to check the binary itself for tell-tale symbols.

The language being used to develop an app has no impact on the language you use to develop a framework.  At the worst, you'll have to provide ObjC-compatible APIs, at least as an option.  (e.g. no Swift structs)
